content.description:
This is a very dynamic problem!

Start on a left-leaning sidepull and make a move out left to a sloping pocket. Set-up your feet high and make a crazy big move to a small, right-leaning crimp. This is a really hard, low percentage move.
content.location: This is the blue route in picture.

content.description: Start on an undercling and move up to a pocket. Then figure out how to get around the bulge and stick the mono - top out.
content.location: This is the red route in the picture.

content.description:
Sunny Day Syd is a short, but fun, compression problem that climbs high quality rock over a perfect landing.

Stand start with a left hand sidepull in a shallow hueco, and a right hand on the arete.  From there, make a big left hand move to the large hueco, slap a right hand up the arete, rein in the weight with a right heel hook, then stick the lip (crux), and top it out.

It goes from a sit start as well, but overall difficulty and quality don't change much though.
content.protection: A pad or two, the landing is great though.
content.location:
This ascends the northeast arete of Main Boulder. It shares the same arete as

A La Torry

, but the style and movement are very different though.

content.description: Stand start with hands on opposing underclings/sidepulls. From there, work straight up the scoop on nice features, reach the lip, and either mantle atop or use a decent sidepull and a high right foot to gain the positive holds further back from the lip to top it out (crux).
content.protection: A pad or two and a spot. The immediate landing is good, but there are a pair of rocks that guard both sides of the landing.
content.location: It climbs the north face of the Main Boulder.

content.description:
You can start lower to make this problem a grade harder.

Start on a right-leaning rail, and make a few moves up and eventually top out - it is a good warmup.
content.location: This is the [yellow] route in the picture.

content.description: Sit start at the crack. From there, follow the crack to reach a featured mantel.
content.protection: A pad or two. The landing is poor, as there is a rock that makes it quite uneven.
content.location: It climbs the north face crack.

content.description:
This is the low start to

Magic Tricks

- you start with a left hand on the original foot rail for

Magic Tricks

and the same right hand pinch. There's a good dish to put your left foot in while your right foot is just smearing the wall. It's only 1 additional hand movement but 3-4 hard foot moves. The group I was with all agreed that the crux to

Magic Tricks

is the dyno itself, and adding the low to it felt equally challenging, if not more.

Magic Tricks

was one of my favorite climbs here, so I wanted to get the low established so others could enjoy it!
content.protection: 2 pads and a few dudes to keep you on them should do just fine!

content.description: Everything is tiny, the last right foot/toe dime hold just before the "dyno" is the worst but provides enough to make the huge move to the finger rail 7-8 feet up from there :)
content.location:
This is just left of

Young Lust

, in the Pink Floyd area.

content.description:
Start on the small right hand crescent hold and the obvious left hand about 8 feet left of

Magic Tricks

. Make a big move straight up with the left hand to a small crimp. Do a big move right to a pinch crimp, and move your left hand to the obvious crimp directly above that right hand crimp. Your right hand goes up to a hatchet blade, little crimp. The next left hand movement goes to a great left hand crimp rail, match on that, and then climb the last 10 feet of the climb on obvious, good holds.
content.location:
It is 8 feet left of

Magic Tricks

.

content.description:
This has an awkward start.

Begin with a left hand on a small crimp and a right hand on a sidepull/pinch... depending on your height, set up on one of the good foot holds. Pull up (don't cheat), hold it, and toss for the big hueco.... It is really the only hard move. Top out.
content.location: This is the purple route in the picture.

content.description:
This is also known as the downclimb on the huge boulder (unless you decide to stack pads and jump off at a low point).

It is a highball problem on big, easy moves... in the center of the boulder.... It is the same grade, I believe, going up any other way.
content.location: This is on the back side of the main boulder. A few different lines are possible on this guy... but for safety reasons, I think cruising the middle of the boulder is probably the most durable, holds wise.

content.description:
A La Torry is a contrivance that stays true to the arete, the east face holds are off.

Stand start with a left hand sidepull in a shallow hueco and a right hand on the arete. From there, move to a perfect, left hand gaston on the arete, gain a thin right hand sidepull, paste a heel, reach the lip, and top it out.

Mileage can be added with a sit start, the difficulty and quality don't change much though.
content.protection: A pad or two, the landing is perfect though.
content.location:
This ascends the Northeast arete of Main Boulder. It shares the same arete as

Sunny Day Syd

, but the style and movement are very different though. A La Torry stays true to the arete versus Sunny Day Syd, which uses the arete and the adjacent east face.
